meanings.def: to use your hands, arms or body in order to make somebody/something move forward or away from you; to move part of your body into a particular position
examples: We pushed and pushed but the piano wouldn't move.
Push hard when I tell you to.
You push and I'll pull.
push at something She pushed at the door but it wouldn't budge.
push somebody/something He walked slowly up the hill pushing his bike.
Somebody pushed me and I fell over.
When you push the gate, it doesn't open.
push somebody/something + adv./prep. She pushed the cup towards me.
He pushed his chair back and stood up.
He tried to kiss her but she pushed him away.
She pushed her face towards him.
push something + adj. I pushed the door open.
He pushed her roughly out of the door.
He was deliberately pushed into the path of the vehicle.
Jack flung himself at Steve, but he simply pushed him away.
She found a note pushed under the door.
She leaned on the box and pushed it aside.
The woman had been pushed violently to the ground.
They pushed the two desks together.
Ellie stood up, pushing her plate away.
I pushed the key into the lock.
The doctor pushed a needle into my arm.

meanings.def: to use force to move past somebody/something using your hands, arms, etc.
examples: People were pushing and shoving to get to the front.
push + adv./prep. The fans pushed against the barrier.
push your way + adv./prep. Try and push your way through the crowd.
A man pushed his way to the front of the crowd.
She pushed blindly past him and made for the door.
Please don't push in front of other customers.

meanings.def: to press a switch, button, etc., for example in order to make a machine start working
examples: I pushed the button for the top floor.
The operator must have accidentally pushed the switch on the joystick.
She pushed a lever and the machine responded.
Push the red button to open the doors.

meanings.def: to affect something so that it reaches a particular level or state
examples: This development could push the country into recession.
The rise in interest rates will push prices up.
Little pent-up demand exists to push the economy forward this year.
The surplus has helped push world prices to as little as 55 euros per tonne.
Such a huge population increase will continue to push food prices higher.
Rising inflation pushes down real interest rates.

meanings.def: to persuade or encourage somebody to do something that they may not want to do
examples: push somebody into something He made it clear that he would resist any attempt to push him into early retirement.
push somebody into doing something My teacher pushed me into entering the competition.
push somebody to do something No one pushed you to take the job, did they?
Her parents pushed her into accepting the job.
She claimed she had been pushed into posing for the photographs.

meanings.def: to make somebody work hard
examples: The music teacher really pushes her pupils.
Lucy should push herself a little harder.
He keeps pushing himself to get better.

meanings.def: to put pressure on somebody and make them angry or upset
examples: Her parents are very tolerant, but sometimes she pushes them too far.
He felt he was being pushed to the limit of his self-control.

meanings.def: to try hard to persuade people to accept or agree with a new idea, buy a new product, etc.
examples: The interview gave him a chance to push his latest movie.
She didn't want to push the point any further at that moment.
He continues to push his own political agenda.
Sales promotion is designed to push certain products.
The two governments are pushing for economic reform in the region.
They're pushing hard for a ban on GM foods.

meanings.def: to sell illegal drugs
to move forward quickly through an area
examples: The army pushed (on) towards the capital.

meanings.def: to be nearly 40, 50, etc. years old
to be dead and buried in the ground
to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you
examples: The prime minister pressed the panic button yesterday as Britain’s economy plunged deeper into crisis.

meanings.def: to do exactly the right things to please somebody
examples: a new satirical comedy show that pushes all the right buttons

meanings.def: to spend a lot of money on enjoying yourself or celebrating something
to attempt to go beyond what is allowed or thought to be possible
examples: We aim to push the boundaries of what we can achieve.
She pushes her physical limits through various endurance challenges.

meanings.def: to go beyond the limits of what is allowed or thought to be possible
examples: He is a performer who consistently pushes the envelope of TV comedy.

meanings.def: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

meanings.def: to force somebody to lose control of their behaviour, usually after a particular event or series of events
examples: No one knows exactly what caused his breakdown, but losing his job may have pushed him over the edge.

meanings.def: to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you
examples: The prime minister pushed the panic button yesterday as Britain's economy plunged deeper into crisis.

meanings.def: to try to forget about something unpleasant
examples: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

idioms.def: to be nearly 40, 50, etc. years old
to be dead and buried in the ground
to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you
examples: The prime minister pressed the panic button yesterday as Britain’s economy plunged deeper into crisis.

idioms.def: to do exactly the right things to please somebody
examples: a new satirical comedy show that pushes all the right buttons

idioms.def: to spend a lot of money on enjoying yourself or celebrating something
to attempt to go beyond what is allowed or thought to be possible
examples: We aim to push the boundaries of what we can achieve.
She pushes her physical limits through various endurance challenges.

idioms.def: to go beyond the limits of what is allowed or thought to be possible
examples: He is a performer who consistently pushes the envelope of TV comedy.

idioms.def: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

idioms.def: to force somebody to lose control of their behaviour, usually after a particular event or series of events
examples: No one knows exactly what caused his breakdown, but losing his job may have pushed him over the edge.

idioms.def: to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you
examples: The prime minister pushed the panic button yesterday as Britain's economy plunged deeper into crisis.

idioms.idiom: push something to the back of your mind
idioms.def: to try to forget about something unpleasant
examples: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

meanings.def: an act of pushing something/somebody
examples: She gave him a gentle push.
The car won't start. Can you give it a push?
(figurative) At the push of a button (= very easily) he could get a whole list of names.

meanings.def: a large and determined military attack
examples: a final push against the enemy
(figurative) The firm has begun a major push into the European market.

meanings.def: a determined effort to achieve something
examples: The push for reform started in 2007.
The company is making a strong push to expand its distribution.
There has been a big push for better public transport.

meanings.def: an act of encouraging somebody to do something
examples: He wants to open his own business, but needs a push in the right direction to get him started.

meanings.def: used to say that something is possible, but only with difficulty
examples: We can provide accommodation for six people at a push.

meanings.def: to dismiss somebody/to be dismissed from your job
examples: They gave him the push after only six weeks.

meanings.def: to end a romantic relationship with somebody; to be told that a romantic relationship with somebody is over
examples: He was devastated when his girlfriend gave him the push.

meanings.def: when there is no other choice; when everything else has failed

idioms.def: used to say that something is possible, but only with difficulty
examples: We can provide accommodation for six people at a push.

idioms.def: to dismiss somebody/to be dismissed from your job
examples: They gave him the push after only six weeks.
He was devastated when his girlfriend gave him the push.

idioms.def: when there is no other choice; when everything else has failed
